author: radekkapka
content: With regards to EIP-7549, why in https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/blob/dev/specs/electra/beacon-chain.md#attestation  `committee_bits` is defined as a bivector, not a bitlist? It's not fixed-length.

author: swp0x0
content:
Hi, I understand that we use the effective balance to minimize the number of hashes we need to do, but I see that actual balances are stored in the BeaconState, which would mean that after each epoch, we update the BeaconState for any actual balance updates as well. According to this logic, EB is not that useful.
I think I am missing how the BeaconState is updated and how often, could someone with better understanding help me out

author: potuz
content: The beacon state is updated on every single slot. It's very likely that many validators will change their balance every slot. Thus that slice needs to be hashed. But the validator structure itself (where the EB is stored) doesn't change that often, and thus it does not need to be rehashed that often

author: swp0x0
content:
If I understand correctly, then the BeaconState gets updated (new Beacon root) in every slot, so the maximum number of hashes to be computed in a slot is probably proportional to the committee size + sync state, etc.
So, an "easy" attack vector to slow down Ethereum is if a lot of validators deposit 1 ETH in a slot. Would the number of hashes be so large that most validators would not be able to do it in the slot time?

author: potuz
content: we do not process more than 16 deposits per slot.

author: potuz
content: hmm that number may be off these days, but still it's bounded and very small
